ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained an appreciation for premodern Russia not within the context of its neighbors to the west, nor as an aside in discussions of more modern history, but instead as a distinct polity with a distinct history, subject to all the usual accidents and historiographic quirks which make the past interesting to study.
Big picture overview of political and military developments of Russian history until the 19th century

I learned a lot about Russia and its pre 19th century history. You really cover a serious amount of content over the semester. Professor Bushkovitch is super knowledgeable and the lectures are concise and digestible. If you are interested in Russia, this is a great survey.

I learned a lot about Russian history and how the culture, religion, and society developed throughout time. This course provided a lot of very interesting primary sources that complimented the history readings really well and gave me an even deeper understanding of the subjects we covered each week.

I learned a lot about the fundamental narratives of Russian history and the drivers of the empire's expansion. We studied the principal rulers and characters from the 9th century onwards and examined in depth the changes in Russia's internal political structure, ethnic/national makeup, and increased relevance on the international scene.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Bushkovitch is a very effective lecturer who clearly knows the content inside and out, and his ability to cover huge swathes of time while still providing specific enough details to give a sense of history as carried out by people instead of abstract concepts was amazing. However, in many cases, it could be difficult to connect one lecture to another along any dimension other than chronology and geography, which could at times make it feel as though two or three different smaller classes were occuring in parallel. The readings were also frequently a bit too detail-oriented as compared to the broad strokes taken in lecture.

I liked the course size but felt that it could have placed more emphasis on what everyday people's lives were like rather than who was in charge because that was often not very significant. Although I felt like I had a good sense of who did what from the throne/government, I didn't always feel like I had a good sense of what life was like in Russia at this point.

Strengths: Comprehensive overview of Russian history and society, manageable workload, Prof. and TA both great and delivered information succinctly; Weaknesses: Readings at times were a bit too tedious and hard to tell what was the most important information to take away from them

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course would likely not be a good choice for a first college level history class, as the level of note-taking and connection forming required to maintain a good grasp on the class themes throughout the centuries would require a steep learning curve. However, for a student with some experience of college level history classes, the reading load is manageable, lectures are engaging and communicate the concepts effectively, and a good understanding of the content can be maintained without excessive studying outside of lecture and section.
I would if you are looking for a light workload lecture with a lot of interesting content and a professor who knows what they are talking about.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student if they are interested in Russian history. Professor Bushkovitch provides an excellent overview of the time period of Russian history covered in the course.
Yes! I'd recommend to someone interested in Russia or imperial history specifically -- otherwise, the material might seem a bit dry.

extras.title: HIST 290 01/RSEE 225 01 - Russia from the 9th C to 1801
